awd_titl_txt: Shapes, Cratering History, and Densities of the Largest Main-Belt Asteroids
awd_abstract_narration:
Moons have been found orbiting some of the largest asteroids in the main asteroid belt, located between the orbits of the planets Jupiter and Mars.  These investigators have obtained telescope time to observe thirty-six large asteroids in the main asteroid belt with an instrument that will provide very high resolution observations of these asteroids.  Their shapes, sizes, any moons that are present, and information about the asteroids' compositions will be uncovered.  All of this information will give the investigators clues about how these multiple-asteroid systems formed and, further, how the major planets in our Solar System formed.  This project serves the national interest by advancing our scientific understanding of how our Solar System formed and changed within its lifetime.  The investigators will tell the story of their research to both students and the general public through undergraduate student research programs, press releases, and social media outlets.  The PI will also develop movies for planetariums through the California Academy of Sciences.

This systematic study will use adaptive optics instrumentation to refine the multiplicity rate of larger main-belt asteroids and will search for a relationship between an asteroid's multiplicity and its composition.  High angular resolution allows the shape models of these asteroids to be measured to unprecedented accuracy.  A study of the orbits of these moons (satellites) will constrain the bulk density of the primary asteroid and provide clues about the composition and distribution of its material, supporting studies addressing the formation of these multiple-asteroid systems in the Solar System.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: The goal of this project is to derive the size and shape of the largest main-belt asteroid in the main-belt using a combination of adaptive optics on 8m class telescopes, as well as small telescopes data collected by rpofessional and amateur astronomers.

We have analyzed and published several shape models of large main-belt asteroids including the first resolved pictures of (2) Pallas and (10) Hygiea published in Nature Astronomy which led to numerous press coverage. The adaptive optics data revealed the cratzerized surface of Pallas implying a violent history and the equilibrium shape of Hygiea which suggests that this asteroid is in fact a dwarf planet.

We also published an update of the shape of (16) Psyche, target of the NASA mission to be launched in 2021. This work will help better planned the objectives of the Psyche mission.

Our group focused their effort  on the last year on developing a coherent model of Kleopatra triple system which resulting in a more accurate shape model and a dynamical model of the moons orbit. Three peer-reviewed articles were publioshed about this system by our group.

Finally, we initiated a new project to develop a Machine Learning algorithm to detect occultation events in data set. This effort was led by a student and published in 2022. The code is routinely used to detect occultation in the Unistellar observations collected by the SETI Institute group (typically 2 events per week).

Broader Impacts:

We also derived an estimate of the shape of the asteroid (943) Begonia using data collected by the Unistellar network, as well as light curve of the asteroid (787) Moksva. This work was done with the contribution of citizen astronomers who used their digital telescope to collect data from their backyard. This is going to be the new direction of our research involving more citizen scientists in the future. 

The PI is also involved in the design of GPI2.0, a new AO system for Gemini North telescope that will include a high resolution camera working in visible light. The funding proposal for this project was accepted by a Canadian agency.

The PI is a member of the GNAO Science definition team, a new AO system in contruction for the Gemini South telescope,  part of the “Gemini in the era of multi-messenger astronomy” (GEMMA) program. He is leading several all the solar system science cases. The report  describing the capability of GNAO is about to be published.

 


Last Modified: 01/27/2023
Modified by: Franck Marchis
